comments.commentBody:
Bullets are an appropriate response to being "chased and punched" by demonstrators?

Why not just leave the scene of the demo?

Here's some speculation of my own: What if these shooters provoked an incident to give them an excuse to start firing?
And would anyone in his right mind ever want to hire one of these protestors? Do they even realize what they are doing to their decent hard working fellow blacks?

.
Of course, by the time the Spacey photo was posted, Deb and Martin already knew "House of Cards" would be in this puzzle's clues.

As I said in Comments on that blog, I enjoyed the 1990s series "House of Cards", although some thought the 3d/final season lacked zing.

It doesn't matter WHAT they are standing up for, nobody has a right to shoot them.

The end.

Jared: you keep writing the same post- so maybe just wait til some facts emerge and then there won't be a problem for you.

Expecting the Times to report a "tangential rumor" is ridiculous.
People who shoot in self defense wait for the police.  They don't run and hide until the police find them.  Give this line of thinking a rest already.

Because 'all lives matter' is a far more accurate, inclusive, respectful and grown up way to convey the message, 'black lives matter' garners rightful automatic suspicion.

There is furthermore a great irony to the BLM phraseology, since several orders of magnitude worth of black lives are taken by blacks, compared to by whites or by police. If it was really about black lives, the campaign would focus on that.

But you and I both know that it is not about black lives.

Meanwhile, plenty of non-white minority immigrants continue to far surpass blacks and even surpass whites by many metrics. That includes African immigrants. Nigerians graduate university in the US at roughly the same rate African Americans graduate high school. And have fewer encounters with police than whites. With the same black skin.

But that doesn't work with the story, does it?

I have a serious question. Is there any governmental entity in Belgium that has jurisdiction over more than three people? I’ve been to Belgium a few times, I like its people, perhaps more the French than the Dutch (who are even more distant than the real Dutch, if that’s possible), but could never understand the basis of their nationhood.

Belgium is what Syria would love to be: multiple distinct tribes that don’t interact so’s you’d notice bundled together in some form of a loose confederation that stays together because it no longer has any external natural predators that could pull it apart. Inertia keeps Belgium together.

I’m not at all surprised that they couldn’t act, even with accurate intelligence, to jointly tie a terrorist’s shoe, much less arrest him.

From the article: "Even if intelligence professionals all speak Belgium's two main languages, they are still divided into feuding fiefs."  The "feuding fiefs" description could have been written about the CIA and FBI (see: Sept.11th).

When did Turkey gets so precious about its borders? Obviously not when thousands of recruits from across the world freely cross from Turkey to Syria to join the Islamic State's barbaric cause. They may as well have a "You Are Now Leaving Turkey - Have a Happy Jihad" sign on their porous border. Yet a Russian plane spends 17 seconds on their side of the line so they blast it out of the sky?

The Islamist government of Turkey has shown by its actions assisting ISIS whose side it is on. Actions always speak louder than words. Now the US and the West will have to show whose side they are on and whether the prime objective in this basketcase region really is wiping out the Islamic State.

The Russians are level headed? I guess that's why they annexed Georgia under Bush, Crimea under Obama, invaded Ukraine. They have engaged in cyber attacks against our government. They have routinely violated our air space and our territorial waters off the east coast with their subs.

As far as Republicans wanting blood? WWI, WWII, the age of nuclear weapons in conventional war, Korea, Vietnam all were Democratic presidents. How much blood was spilled then?

And don't forget the over 525 drone attacks by Obama that have killed hundreds of innocent people, his 30,000 troop surge and of course going into Iraq without Congressional approval.

It is simply to deal with; the Russians will simply arm the PKK with any anti-tank weapons and small arms that they require.  The Turks will find out what payback really means when they lose part of Turkey to Kurdistan.

.
.
Congratulations and welcome to the debut constructors!

I was not bothered by the items Deb noted; I just liked seeing the puns unfold. And for some reason, I set a new personal speed record for the 3d day in a row. As was the case Tuesday, I broke my old record by more than a minute. I think the answer for 1 Across IMPEIled me to move quickly through the clues.

Welcome shoutout to the people of Paris in that clue. Did anyone else hear President Obama trying to say French phrases during his joint appearance today with French President Hollande? Wow. For some reason, U.S. voters don't like electing people who can properly pronounce French words, like John Kerry and Mitt Romney.

Yes, as you mentioned NATO (which includes the US so no need to mention them separately) has tried to go at it the diplomatic way rather than the military way, so you are blaming it for trying to be the grown up in this situation? Hmm.  I'm sure the rest of the world prefers it that way, but of course Putin is always looking to create conflicts in order to consolidate his power.  As bad as ISIS has been for Syria Assad has been much worse and of course with the help of Putin.  Remember, ISIS sprung up as an opposition to Assad!  Are you suggesting that NATO should have gone to war against Russia over the Ukraine?  Would you have been ready to enlist and go to fight a third world war in Europe?  Obama is stuck cleaning up after the horrible mess that the Bush administration left behind and it won't be easy and it will take time. And still conservatives are ready to jump up and down to criticize while their candidates have absolutely no clue about the situation and no plan to deal with it.

Here are Erdoğan's words when Syria shot down Turkey's F-4 back in 2012:
"A short-term border violation can never be a pretext for an attack,"

Russia's Su-24 was in Turkey for less than 30 seconds. You make your own conclusion.

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-18598529

Light and fluffy, super delicious!  I used baking powder instead of baking soda since the cocoa contains alkali and added semisweet chocolate chips because the chocolate flavor is subtle and I wanted to top with vanilla frosting.

ISIS is the terrorist organization getting help from the Turkish Government. Please do your homework and look up how Erdogan is
treating Turkish dissidents and yes, minorities in his country.

What would the U.S. do if its airspace was violated? How many seconds do you think it would take us to scramble our fighters if there was an approaching military jet and shoot it down if it ignored our warnings?

Not so clear when the shoe is on the other foot, is it?

Paul, respectfully, I'd sure like to see a link to an article regarding Garber's hoping for a Red Bull-Galaxy final a year ago. The MLS final on Dec. 6 is going to be broadcast on national TV, and every ardent MLS supporter everywhere, regardless of their club, is going to be watching. MLS, which doesn't get the hype other US sports leagues get, doesn't get many casual observers, I don't think. In other words, viewership will hardly be affected, no matter who's in. A lot folks are thrilled when smaller-market teams triumph, just like we enjoy seeing big-money Prem teams get knocked out of the FA Cup by Championship giant killers (I should add I'm delighted to see Chelsea in 15th place). And what club anywhere has a "national following" when it comes to domestic league play?

The problem with this team starts on the defensive side of the ball, particularly third down. We are "playing from behind" in the first quarter.

Secondary needs to be about who is playing best, not who has the biggest contract, and we need to generate consistent pressure up front.

The linebackers are the strength and only get "revealed" as "weak in pass coverage" when hung out to dry.

The offense needs to return to its early season efficiency. A couple of plays in each of the last two games turns them into wins.

But this defense can't stop teams in critical moments, and it's starting to show.

@ Indrid Cold

Thanks very much for sharing your experience.

It is shameful that our govt's 'Drug War' is having such a negative impact on those who are receiving medical treatment.

All of us need to be aware that it is possible that someday we could be in Severe Pain, whether through disease, accident or old age.  

Do we want a culture that makes medications to relieve pain expensive and hard to obtain ?

I'm going to provide an excellent example of serious harm that current drug laws are causing. I am speaking a s a daily user of a schedule 2 opioid drug. That drug is hydrocodone. I use it daily as prescribed 4 times per day, to treat an incurable, and extremely painful neuromuscular illness. Since it was reclassified as a schedule 2 drug, I have experienced inconvenience, and abuse at the hands of those who seek to prevent this medication from falling into the wrong hands. This includes monthly doctor visits (as opposed to every three months) which my insurance company reimburses at a rate of $420 per month, thus inflating the cost of medical care by god-only knows how much. I'm told this is the most widely prescribed pain killer in the nation. Imagine what utterly draconian drug laws are doing to your health insurance premiums?!  All because of laws to prevent safe and legal prescriptions from being written. And you thought the HUMAN cost was unconscionable. The dollar cost is no small matter either.

It wasn't just crime.  Alcohol-related illness may have risen after Prohibition, but at the same time, blindness and death from drinking wood alcohol dropped from epidemic levels to practically nothing. Wealthier people could afford bootleg, but hospitals and morgues were filled with poorer people who could only afford toxic imitations.  They weren't deterred by the law.  They were killed by it.
Why are the garlic cloves "unpeeled"?  I don't understand the reasoning.

I wouldn't say bothered, but I did trip up by writing in AMOCK, which looked weirdish but seemed like a likely variation of AMOK. Then when TUT made it AMUCK, I figured that's why AMOCK looked weird: it was wrong! But ... AMUCK?

Here's what the Grammarist site says:

"Amok is the 21st-century standard spelling of the word meaning (1) in a frenzy to do violence, or (2) in an uncontrolled state. Amuck is an old alternative spelling of the Malaysian loanword, and it had a few decades of prevalence before the middle 20th century, but it has now fallen out of favor. A few usage authorities still recommend the latter spelling, but amok is preferred in edited writing of this century."

-- good! Because I prefer AMOK, too: it makes me think of Vikings.

There was a TV show (only on for one season, 1965-66) called Camp Runamuck, about the hijinks that could be gotten into by kids at a boys' summer camp that was across a lake from a girls' summer camp.  And I think people (when I was a kid, and in central NC) more usually said 'amuck' rather than 'amok.'  That said, I've gotten more used to hearing 'amok' in recent decades.
I AM OK with AMOK, but I AM UCK with AMUCK.
Am I the only one slightly bothered by 'run amuck?'

Why is Turkey still in NATO? For someone who is suppose to be an ally they did nothing to aid he coalition in Desert Storm. They have done nothing to aid in the war on terror and reports indicate that the Russian fighter barely entered into Turkish air space and that the Turkish response was clearly an overreaction on their part. To me that begs the question; what is their end game? Were they trying to send a message? Were they trying to quell any doubts about their commitment to NATO? They are playing a very dangerous game. But by far the most horrific part of it was as the pilots parachuted the Turks shot and killed the 2 pilots as they descended to earth. I think NATP should meet and expel Turkey. To kill 2 helpless pilots in this manner to me deserves expulsion and those responsible be tried for war crimes.

Finally, Putin has indicated that Russia will make a very strategic and bold response. I would bet that they will hit key infrastructure facilities as well as key military installations. And then how will Turkey respond and will NATO support them. That's when the rubber meets the road
